review.title: Auto-JacoBin: Auto-encoder Jacobian Binary Hashing
review.abstract: Binary codes can be used to speed up nearest neighbor search tasks in large scale data sets as they are efficient for both storage and retrieval. In this paper, we propose a robust auto-encoder model that preserves the geometric relationships of high-dimensional data sets in Hamming space. This is done by considering a noise-removing function in a region surrounding the manifold where the training data points lie. This function is defined with the property that it projects the data points near the manifold into the manifold wisely, and we approximate this function by its first order approximation. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves better than state-of-the-art results on three large scale high dimensional data sets.

sections.heading: V. SUMMARY
sections.text: In this thesis, we have proposed a novel hashing algorithm that adopts the auto-encoder model to generate binary codes that geometrically match the data points in the original space. We have used the advantages of modern models for auto-encoders. We have introduced a new objective function that uses the properties of first-order geometric conservation (the Jacobin matrix) and has good properties for noise reduction. We have proven that the Jacobin method of defined function can be used to approximate the tangential space of the manifold of the training dataset and to show how the Jacobin properties can be expressed analytically. Experiments are carried out on three large datasets. The performance of the proposed method is compared with several state-of-the-art hashing algorithms, providing the best performance for global image functions and comparable performance for the SIFT feature data sets.

metadata.abstractText: Binary codes can be used to speed up nearest neighbor search tasks in large scale data sets as they are efficient for both storage and retrieval. In this paper, we propose a robust auto-encoder model that preserves the geometric relationships of high-dimensional data sets in Hamming space. This is done by considering a noise-removing function in a region surrounding the manifold where the training data points lie. This function is defined with the property that it projects the data points near the manifold into the manifold wisely, and we approximate this function by its first order approximation. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves better than state-of-the-art results on three large scale high dimensional data sets.
